text:
I've made this recipe as is with the fried fish and it is great, but I have also grilled the fish and it has come out even more tasty.  I marinate the fish in lime and a bit of jalapenos to add flavor, and just dust with chili powder and salt before grilling.  They come out moist and tasty, and best of all healthier!  I also suggest using cabbage slaw mixture instead of just straight cabbage.  It adds color and flavor as well.  The sauce is amazing as is though.  None of the flavors are too overpowering, and it's so tangy on the fish, a perfect combination!

Display Name:
Ben Greenwood

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Muy bueno!
* To make it lighter/healthier, double up the lime and jalapeno juice. After you've prepped the chipotle with some of the juice, add some olive oil, and use the rest to marinade the fish. I George Forman'ed the fish, but fry pan or baking/broiling would work too. If you have fast fingers, and you want to make it easier, cut the fillets after frying.
* If your palate is sensitive to spicy, drop the jalapeno. If jalapeno is too sour for you, replace with smaller(!) amount of habanero.
* If you have a vegetable/fruit juicer, it cuts down on the prep time of the lime and jalapeno/habanero.
* Side this with avacado or guac.
* Side this with (easy) beans and rice. Remove 1/3 cup of water before boiling. When adding brown rice, throw in a can of black beans. Do this before cooking the fish, since brown rice takes about 25-30 minutes to soak up the water. Some people subtract more water and also throw in a can of stewed tomatoes. I like to add garlic powder.
* Heat up the corn tortillas before serving. If you don't have a tortilla warmer, then make sure you fold in half before they cool.
* Capers are just a garnish, don't worry if you can't find any.
* If you are opposed to beer, use ginger ale.
* If you don't have cod, any white fish will do. Some people have had success with salmon.
* If cutting cabbage is a pain for you, use a package of mix and serve cole slaw, tossing the cole slaw packet.
* Add cilantro and/or pink onion as a garnish or into the cabbage.

text:
5 stars is not high enough for this recipe. I give it 100 stars!! Yum, Yum Yummy! I cannot believe how delicious the beer batter was. It's such a simple recipe, but it's so light and crispy and scrumptious. The white sauce was very, very good...hmm, I'm sorry, I meant to say excellent! I used sourcream instead of yogart. I was leery of the capers..because I don't like them, so I minced the heck out of them so they would just kinda get lost in the sauce and provide flavor. I used 1/2 of the cayenne pepper, because that would be just too hot for my kids, and it had plenty of kick, and my kids still complained. I made a double batch of the white sauce, and I am so glad I did, because we lapped up just about ever bit I made. I also made up some fresh Pico De Gallo..it's simple to make and you can find that recipe everywhere on line. It added such a freshness to this meal. It was nice to make something for dinner tonight that I didn't open a jar or some pre made thing. I prepared everthing from scratch except for the corn tortillas. I used the corn tortillas and soft fried them..they were perfect. OH MY GOD, I can't wait to make these again. Be sure to make the sauce ahead of time so it will have time for all those ingredients to blend. I gave it 8 hours, but at least 2 would be sufficient.Try this recipe, it is worth the time and effort, and the batter would be terrific in many other types of things to fry.

text:
This was a great fast and easy recipe to make for dinner. I substituted light sour cream for the yogurt and used light mayo. As some reviewers suggested, I used fresh, minced cilantro instead of oregano and fresh minced dill.  Instead of frying, I coated the cod w/ olive oil, lime, s&p and grilled it.  Right before I took the fish off the grill, I put the corn tortillas directly on the grill and only slightly toasted them on each side.  This definitely cuts any frying to make this a more diet friendly recipe. Great for casual outdoor dining.

text:
Awesome. I made this mostly for the sauce, I did not fry the fish- just cooked in a pan with a splash of olive oil. Sauce was great, used low fat yogurt and mayo, cut the seeds and membrane out of half the pepper, but not the other. It was spicy, but that's ok, because all the flavors came through. I only used maybe a teaspoon of sauce on each taco and it was very good. Also made some guac and put on the tacos. Good stuff.

text:
What made these tacos amazing was the white sauce. I was sceptical upon reading the ingredients, but it was awesome. The contrast in textures also made this a perfect meal.  the crunchy battered fish with the soft tortillas and the cooling sauce...a masterpiece on the tongue.  Do not forget to serve this with a cold beer.
Also, my only criticism of this recipe was that the batter lacked "punch".  We added a few dashes of salt to the fish immediately after being taken out of the fryer, it made a huge difference.  We also served the tacos w/ a homemade salsa which was good, but probably not essential. 
Overall, this is a rockin' taco...I'll definitley make these again.

I did salt the fish after frying.  My modifications to the sauce:  I used nonfat yogurt, light mayo, pickled jalepeno, subbed mexican oregano, added some ancho powder . . . we couldn't get enough! The sauce is an important component - the ingredients may sound a bit odd to some but it  works to a T.  Can't wait to have it again!

text:
Good recipe, trick with batter is do not whisk too hard.  You must not break up the bubbles from the beer, otherwise the will become too bready and not puff up.  Also, sauce needs a little salt.

text:
I made the fish my own way - breaded with flour and cornmeal and broiled four minutes each side (used Tilapia). I made a double recipe of the sauce (nixed the cumin but only because I didn't have any) and mixed about half of it with a bag of shredded coleslaw blend (no regular coleslaw sauce of course). I put the rest of the sauce in a bowl incase anyone wanted more. I was a little skeptical about the sauce because I didn't really like it straight from the bowl as I was making it (did use sour cream not yogurt). But once I put it on the taco with the fish and the cabbage blend - wow! It was really good! Gave the tacos a great fresh taste. We also added slices of avocado. I forgot to put it out but next time we plan to sprinkle some cilantro on top of it also. Yum! Thanks for a great sauce! UPDATE - I added some fresh cilantro to the next tacos and some very thinly sliced onions as well - wow. Even better flavor...

text:
We love fish tacos but they are REALLY REALLY good when put in a crispy corn taco shell! An alternative to frying fish is to chop it into chunks and sprinkle with salt, cumin, and a bit of butter, toss and bake it on a cookie sheet at 400 until done. About 10 minutes or so.

text:
This was fantastic! By far one of my favorite recipes from this site, and one of the only ones I've never "tweaked". Per another member's suggestion, the first time I made it I used Mahi Mahi, which was wonderful. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly as written. The fresh lime really made all the difference. And although somewhat time consuming, it wasn't so difficult that I won't make it again and again. The beer batter recipe was a great one and even if you don't want to make tacos, it's great for just making fish and chips, too. I made this again, trying to be healthy and just used grilled fish, nonfat yogurt and light mayo, and instead of cabbage I used "broccoli slaw" which looks like coleslaw and comes already cut up and pre-packaged. Even this way, it was GREAT! I don't think you can go wrong with this sauce no matter how you make your tacos.

text:
Thankyou for taking me home to San Diego! I've missed Rubio's Fish Tacos so much. Being a mom with not much time on my hands, I skipped the battering part and instead soaked pre-battered fish fillets in beer and then crisped them in the oven. In my opinion, it turned out just like Rubio's. The sauce was WAY too spicy for me. To mend the sauce to my taste buds, I tripled everything except the cayenne and jalapenos. I decided to freeze the extra into single serving freezer containers to save me time in the future. I'll give you 5 stars because you've met my craving. This was the closest to Rubios I've found since moving away from SD 5 years ago. Thanks for sharing.

text:
This recipe was flawless. The absolute best recipe I've tried on this site and I've been on here for years! I used Bud Lime for the beer batter. I also added lemon pepper to flour to dust the tilapia in before dipping in the beer batter. For the sauce, I did not have capers so I minced 1 tbsp of green olives. I used sour cream instead of yogurt. I used 1 tbsp dill pickle juice instead of dill weed. I also cut the cayenne to half of a teaspoon. It still had a lovely kick, but was not overpowering. I mixed the sauce with a prepackaged undressed coleslaw of cabbage and carrots. I put fish and coleslaw on corn tortillas garnished with a little cilantro. I served the fish tacos with homemade mango salsa and tortilla chips and black beans. My family went nuts over it. Will definitely be making this many, many times. Thanks for a great recipe! It was just like eating a phenomenal fish taco at the beach!

country:
None
text:
Mexican sour cream (added to the mayo & lime) is a lot better tasting and more authentic than yogurt. Also, be warned that buying substitutions for this recipe yield badly tasting results. Use quality beer (preferably Mexican) and lime. No lemon, as it will cause the sauce to taste quite different. To save oil, I used a smaller sauce pot for the deep fry and to cut calories, I steamed the tortillas in the microwave rather than fried. Make a homemade salsa of cilantro, red onions, Lowry's garlic pepper, and fresh tomatoes for added flavor and health.  =)

text:
We really like fish tacos and thought these were great.  I added 1/4 tsp black pepper to the batter and had to add a little more beer as it was a little too thick.  The batter made enough for 2 lbs. of fish cut into strips to get more crispy edges.  I warmed the tortillas in the oven instead of frying and pan-fried the fish in just a couple of tablespoons of oil at a time...way less than the specified amount of a full quart.  The batter provides a crispness and doesn't have a lot of flavor, but that is what the spicy sauce in this recipe is for.  I thought the sauce was very good, but I would add some cilantro next time as it had more of a herby-spicy flavor as written (from the dill & oregano).

This was outstanding!! I love the fish tacos at Trudy's in Austin, and these taste very similar. 

I made a few modifications: 
I couldn't find Cod, so I used frozen Tilapia. 
Instead of the beer batter, I dredged the fish in egg and then in seasoned flour (I initially made the beer batter, but it tasted gross. May have been the beer i used). 
I substituted vanilla yogurt for the plain and omitted the capers because I don't care for them.   
I served with flour tortillas and red cabbage, and of course a cold Shiner Bock.  

I really love this sauce and I think I can use it for more dishes.

It was fabulous! Thanks for sharing!

userID:

Display Name:
Jennifer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Used the recipe as a base, but broiled the tilapia.  I thought this was fantastic and extremely quick to make (start to finish only 20 min)!  I did modify quite a bit based on my personal tastes and what I had on hand. 
Sauce: I did not have any limes, so I used lemons and sauce tasted great.  I did not use capers (not a fan) and did not have any jalapeno peppers, so skipped those as well. I used plain greek yogurt and light mayo and it turned out delicious.  It definitely had a little kick to it, even without the jalapenos. 
Fish: melted a TBSP of butter and brushed both sides of the fish, sprinkled with Hawaiian salt and pepper.  Placed on baking sheet with non stick tin foil and then broiled for ~ 9 minutes: 3 min. on one side, flipped them and broiled for another 3 min., then took the sauce and brushed it on the top side of the fish and broiled for another 2-3 min. Placed the fish inside heated soft taco shells, spooned the sauce over and enjoyed. SO GOOD!!!! I could eat that every night.  Can't wait to experiement with various toppings: corn, black beans, cilantro, cabbage, etc.  
As a side note, I think the sauce would be great on any fish and even the toppings.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
These were delicious. I'd rather eat this than go to a restaurant, and they were fun to make. I found I was out of cumin for the white sauce, so I skipped it and it was still great. Forgot to dredge the fish in flour before frying, and it made no difference. Subbed lettuce for the cabbage. Really delicious recipe, and though I thought it would be time consuming it really took no more work than when I usually make fried fish. The beer batter recipe here isn't the best out there, but it works just fine for the dish. If you want a top-notch beer batter, try the "Beer Batter for Fish" recipe for this site, which includes some more seasoning. But, for how fast and easy the beer batter here was, it works fine.

text:
I lived in San Diego for 17 yrs. and fish tacos were found everywhere.  Living in Florida now and they arn't as popular here.  Most of my family in Florida had never heard of fish tacos.  I will have to say that this recipe is the best.  The sauce is something to die for.  I did cut back on the jalapeno and cayenne pepper (to my taste).  I added salt & pepper to the flour before dusting the fish.  I didn't change the fish batter at all.  Loved it.  I used flour tortillas and heated them in a salted hot skillet (no oil). I would put these up against any fish taco in San Diego as being one of the best recipes I have tried. Didn't use cod. I caught and cleaned the fish myself which made the recipe more special.  Thank you for the recipe.  It will be used often.

text:
Beer batter is out of this world.  Just like in the restaurants and so amazingly easy to make at home.  The white sauce was great - really fresh tasting.  I've made this many times and only add a few pinches of cumin, garlic salt, paprika and 1 tablespoon dill.  Just adjust to your taste.  If something sounds like it would be too much for you, then decrease or just cut it out.  This is one of our weekeday dinners and it's fast to put together.  Serve with shredded lettuce, red cabbage, cilantro, some chopped tomatoes and you're set.  Just use what ever you have on hand.  Super versatile and has a great fresh taste.

text:
I live in SoCal and like to fish the local saltwater. One of the species that we get here in the beginning of summer is California Barracuda. A fun fish to catch, but not always so fun to eat, and you really need to eat it the same day you catch it. They're fairly large fish too, so I need to get as many people fed as I can. This is one of the few recipes I've found that does this fish justice and keeps people from asking too many questions about what kind of fish they're eating! Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
WOW! This recipe is spot on! Made them tonight and have to say they are just about the best Fish Tacos I have ever tasted. I made the sauce exactly as directed expect I only used a half of a jalapeno because my jalepeno was HUGE! I used Wahoo filets instead of cod, which were amazing! The trick to getting the fish perfectly crispy is to make the batter at the last second right before you drop the fish in the fryer so you don't mess with all the wonderful beer bubbles! And then instead of draining the fish on paper towels, set a rack on a cookie sheet and put the cooked fish on the rack to drain while waiting in a warm oven for the rest of the fish to cook. Thank you so much for the recipe! Will definately be making this again, and again, and again! :)

text:
I use allrecipes.com all the time, but I've never written a review before. I had to this time because I think this might have been the most delicious meal I've ever made! I cheated and used frozen battered fish fillets (baked, not fried) and for an even healthier option I used both fat free mayo and fat free yogurt and I promise you it was still amazing! You would not even notice the missing fat because the recipe is so good. The sauce does come out very, very spicy but I love spicy food so it was ok for me. If you are not a fan of super hot foods I would recommend cutting back to 1/2 tsp. on the cayenne and just adding slowly to your taste. Thank you Tanya--this was wonderful!! I will make it again often! PS I think the sauce would even be delicious as a dip, sandwich spread or even salad dressing. It is SO good!

This is a fantastic recipe.  I used sour cream in lieu of the yogurt in the white sauce since I usually watch my carb intake.  Also I make a relish out of corn, chopped red peppers and red onion. text:
Very good.  This does have a bit of a bite and next time I'll cut the cayenne pepper in half.  You will have A LOT of batter left over.  Next time I will cut the sauce in half for our family of 4.  I will also try cilantro next time. I used large flour tortillas and I think it would have been better with smaller corn tortillas.  I agree with everyone who said the fried fish lacked flavor...I would salt & pepper before battering.  I did look up a beer batter recipe on allrecipes and they included 1 tsp of garlic powder & 1/2 tsp of blk pepper...I wonder if that would do the trick.  I used a wok with oil for frying (it does splatter quite a bit though)...med-high heat for about 5 mins.  It was a total of about 15 min cook time. Overall the sauce was very flavorful.  I used a cheap beer, but my hubby claims the cheaper beers cook a better flavor.

text:
A bit messy and time consuming.  I wish I would have grilled my fish instead of frying, but wanted to try this as written.  I am in the minority on the sauce, I think.  It wasn't my favorite - it was a bit too thick for my taste and even though I used a bit less dill, it seems all I tasted was dill.  Almost like a glorifed tartar sauce.  I've had tons of SD fish tacos - both fried and blackened - and this didn't really remind me of my favorites.  Also, the batter is quite bland.  I took the advice of another reviewer and seasoned my fish before batter and used a couple shakes of seasoned salt when the fish was done cooking.  Overall; it was just too bland, greasy and tartar-y for me.  I doubt I'll try this one again, sorry.

None
text:
This review is only for the sauce. (I grilled my fish) I found this sauce to be gritty from the spices. I really think this should be made at least 24 hours ahead of time to soften the dry spices and blend the flavors. Or maybe it would help to allow the spices to macerate in the lime juice for a couple hours first. I also did not care for the crunchy jalapenos.  I would prefer the softer pickled jalapenos (which would compliment the capers as well). While trying to fix this to suit our tastes, I added a drizzle of honey, salt and pepper, and a little minced pickle. Then I added a LOT of minced pickle. It began to taste a lot like tartar sauce so I quit tweaking around with it. The sauce was edible and did not ruin our meal, but I won't make this again as written.

text:
More like TEN stars!!! Holy  (which is a odd saying lol *shrug) these were BANGIN delicious! I can't praise them enough. Ppl couldn't stop eating them and all said this was better than any restaurant. I seasoned the flour mixture with chili powder, a bit of Adobo and S&P- PERFECT for me, but my son said it was a little on the bland side (he ate the fish plain and not with all the taco fixings). I left out the capers and subbed cilantro for the oregano. Used a dark lager beer (amber brock). And served with pico de gallo. I made the white sauce and pico de gallo that morning so the flavors could marinate all day. Served with brown rice and black beans (for which I sauteed minced garlic and a little onion first, used Adobo chicken broth instead of water for rice, subtracted about a third cup liquid and replaced with a can of drained black beans...so good). Will reheat the fish under the broiler for yummy leftovers today-can't wait! I could eat these things for breakfast lol. So good.

userID:
4199716
Display Name:
Vagabum Mike
isPro:

2

recipesCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/437271.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I also grew up in San Diego and the first of that amazing SD fish taco chain opened up next to my high school in 1983. I always hit them up first when I return and although they have a few franchises in San Francisco they are not nearly as good. Well this recipe more than satisfies my craving and man are these tacos great.   I made the recipe as described but used light Greek yogurt and light Miracle Whip instead of mayo. I also added 1/2 Tsp of Caper juice and the sauce was out of this world. I used cooking spray to lightly fry the tortillas and it just doesn't taste as good as oil. I also put a bit of Jack cheese in between the lightly fried and warmed tortillas. I topped the tacos with cilantro the white sauce and a bit of fresh Tomatillo Salsa.  With the fish I suggest making the fish pieces smaller, say 1 1/3 to 1 1/2 oz to better fit the tortilla (thick and more narrow so there is still room for cabbage, guac and salsa). For leftovers put the fish in the toaster oven to get that amazing crisp and fresh texture back.

text:
Holy Gawd is this fabulous!!!!! I have made it several times now, and depending on what I have to hand, it comes out a little differently each time....and ALWAYS wonderful! The sauce is what makes this a 5 star recipe. I use a pre-shredded cole slaw mix, which saves time and adds even more flavor. I have added fresh corn kernels shaved from the cob in this and found it was soooo good! The last timeI made this recipe, I did not bread the fish, just fried it in a bit of coconut oil...husband and I both agreed that it was just as yummy...saves calories and carbs too! Also, I used flour tortillas, which we prefer with this recipe. The pico de gallo and limes are a great addition. I could eat this every day!

Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I made this, I had never had a fish taco in my life, so I had nothing to compare it to, but I gotta say YUMM!! My husband who doesn't like fish loved these, especially the sauce and beer batter. After making it a few times, I've come up with a way we like it best. I've always used tilapia, because that's what I always have on hand. I sprinkle a little seasoning salt on the battered fish right after it comes out of the oil. I didn't have capers the first time I made it, and we loved it, so I've never used them. I usually add more jalapeno and cayenne (depending on who's eating), double the cumin and dill weed, I add bay seasoning, and I put a few cloves of garlic in the sauce. Sour cream is interchangeable with yogurt, I use whatever I have on hand. Pico de gallo is a must for us. I make it from a recipe on this site. I've tried flour tortillas and fried corn tortillas and the fried corn tortillas win every time. I have enjoyed it with flour tortillas and grilled fish (for healthiness) and I like it, but my husband and I far prefer the whole fried deal. A+

text:
I'm from San Diego too and no longer live there - these are wonderful and do taste like home.  I've been trying to find a recipe similar to fish tacos down there and this is it!  Deep frying can be a pain - my deep fryer was small so I had to do several batches of fish, which precluded eating dinner as a family since I had to man the fryer.

The only change I made was to only add 1/2 tsp cayenne and 1/2 jalapeno pepper to the white sauce, since I thought it would be too spicy otherwise.  It was perfect.  I served it with pico de gallo (from the Black Beans and Pico de Gallo recipe from this site).  Delicious.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/109052.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow, this recipe is outstanding. I have never deep-fried so I was a bit little nervous. It was very easy and the fish turned out perfectly fried, almost like it came from a fish n' chips place! I bought a liquid (candy/deep fry) thermometer and kept it in the deep pot I  used with 2 pints of vegetable oil. The temperature fluctuated a lot but this was to be expected (it went between 350-400). Making the beer batter was quick and easy and after a few minutes in the hot grease the fish (I used fresh grouper) was golden, crisp and yummy.  
The sauce was also outstanding. I had to use chili powder instead of cayenne pepper because I didn't have any. It was still good although I'm sure it changed the flavor from the original recipe. 
I served the tacos with lettuce and toms because my grocery store didn't have any cabbage! 
Also, I think that frying the tortillas is unnecessary and too greasy. I think it would be better to heat them in the microwave.
It was delicious and my family was impressed and loved it.

Fish tacos are my favorite and we loved these. The sauce was great too. I used chipotles (smoked jalepenos) instead of regular because that was what I had.

OMG! Like my kids say!  These were sooo good!  Everyone is right, this is an unbelieveable combo.  I too used lite sour cream, but I added a tsp of chopped garlic & a tiny bit of crushed ginger.  I left out the japs due to the kids, and its a good thing I did because my 10 yr old picked up on the smidge of cayenne I put in. My husband LOVED these! He immediately said "put these on our list of foods".
The sauce was very good. I agree with another user to let the sauce sit for a few hours, because when I ate it on my taco after I fixed it, it was okay, I didn't see the big deal. But when I ate some more about 4 hours later with some more fish, it was delicious.
I also used tilapia since that's what we had on hand and I didn't put capers or jalapenos in the sauce. And we topped our tacos with the white sauce, cabbage and Pico de Gallo. Delicious!

text:
I was so happy to find this recipe because it tastes just like the wonderful fish tacos we have when we visit San Diego. I usually just buy beer battered cod and deep fry them instead of making my own batter.  I have baked the fish but deep frying is so much better.  I use sour cream instead of the yogurt and leave out the capers and adjust the cayenne pepper for my kids sake. Just make sure to have fresh lime wedges to squeeze over each taco right before you eat it and it is complete perfection!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these tacos twice, thinking I'd done something wrong the first time, but no: the recipe for the batter is too bready.  The white sauce is good, but the beer batter recipe ruins the fish - creating a soggy fishstick texture in the freshly fried fish. A hint:  if you want your fish crispy - 2 cups of flour per 12 oz bottle of beer, two teaspoons of salt and NOTHING ELSE!  the eggs, cornstarch etc. are completely unnecessary.  In the white sauce, I cut the cayenne and jalapeños and doubled the dill.

text:
I am always looking for new ways to serve fish, and this recipe caught my eye!  I did change it up a little bit by making it into a Fish Taco Salad!  I used hearts of romaine, a shredded cabbage mix, chopped up avocado, a fresh tomato, chopped red onion, and corn tortilla chips.  I followed the recipe exactly for the sauce and used that as the salad dressing, except I used nonfat vogurt and light mayo (you wouldn't even notice) and it was awesome, I loved the flavors of the capers and jalapeño!  I used a fresh piece of cod, but really any cut of fish would work!  Can't wait to make it again!

Thank you Tanya for this tasty new dish. text:
This was my first time having, much less making fish tacos. I don't like fried foods, so I marinated the mahi mahi in lemon (didn't have a lime) and juice from the canned jalapeno peppers. I pan-seared the fish in a cast iron skillet with no oil and cut it up in the pan so it would be blacked and seared. 

The sauce is fantastic! I used canned jalapenos and sour cream instead of mayo. It was spicy and so very good. 

My husband loved this dish and I'll be making it again.

I do not own a deep frier, so I fried our fish (mahi mahi) in a pan with about 1/2 inch of vegetable oil and the results were FABULOUS. I had never attempted fried fish tacos at home before, and have to admit that I was a bit nervous… but I was so pleased with the results! Even my husband who swears up and down that he doesn't like fish, loved these. He ate SIX! 

A few tips:: I added some seasoning to the batter itself to kick up the flavour a bit. Just some cumin, cayenne, salt and pepper. You could really jazz it up however you like. The fish was really tasty and could easily have been eaten on its own.

text:
just my 2¢
not any "beer" will work for this. skip the pale vienna and american lagers and instead choose a malty ale, like an amber or (english) ESB or an american Pale, you will be much more astounded by beer that actually contributes flavor. 
i skipped the capers and despite the photo of cilantro that was not in the recipe (unless i am blind) i added it along with fresh pico de gallo and red onions in favor of yellow. this calls for cod, but don't overlook whiting, halibut or mahi mahi. oh, and vanilla bean ice cream topped with apple crumble is amazeballs with fish tacos. NOM!

text:
I made these last night, and yes, with some changes. I did not fry or batter the fish. I baked it on a ridged sheet pan at 400 * for about 15-20 mins, turning once. I used tilapia and removed the thin edge ( since it would only be dry) and cut each filet lengthwise in half. I dusted each with seasoned salt, pepper, cumin, paprika and oregano. For the sauce, I used 1/2 C each sour cream & mayo, the juice of 1 1/2 lemons (it's what I had) and 1 tsp each cumin, chili powder, oregano & cayenne pepper. Served with shredded lettuce, cheese & flour tortillas. Everyone loved these and there were -0- left overs. I will make these again!

I was  looking for an amazing recipe for fish Tacos, trying to introduce some new flavors to many of my families' boring meals. I came across this recipe and was a little intimidated at first to try this as it's a little time consuming. However, it worked out well and the video was a big help. I used Blue Moon beer. Display Name:
EmmLee
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this recipe last night, nearly as written. It turned out really well. 

VERY MINOR CHANGES: 
1) I seasoned the flour I use to coat the fish prior to dipping into the batter with a tbs of Badia Sazon Tropical (a blend of salt, black pepper, garlic, onion, oregano, paprika, and cumin). 

2)I also substituted sour cream for yogurt in the sauce. I also added 1 tsp cilantro, changed the tsp of cayenne to 1/2 tsp cayenne + 1/2 tsp ground chipotle, added a pinch of sugar since not using yogurt, and salt & pepper to taste. 

3) I made the batter a bit thinner by adding more beer, so that I had less of a thick pancake coating. It was almost the consistency of gravy, but made for a light, crispy coating. 

4) I did not fry my tortillas, but wrapped them in a damp paper towel and warmed them in the microwave. Also did not use cabbage, but had shredded lettuce, diced tomato and diced avocado, as well as pico and salsa verde for toppings

5) For this go-round, I used tilapia filets (I'd already used my cod for fish-n-chips). They worked out REALLY well. First time cooking tilapia, and pleased with results

TIPS: drain the cooked fish on brown paper bags set on cookie sheets. It absorbs the oil and helps it from getting soggy. You can also keep them in a warm oven on the brown bags while cooking in batches. The fish stayed crispy and did not overcook. You can reheat leftover fish on greased cookie cooling racks and it turns out crispy and delicious (same as with other fried foods).

text:
Even with all the cayenne and jalapenos (I used 1.5 canned), it was not as hot and spicy as I expected.  But the tang of the yogurt and the overall flavor for fish tacos was very good.  The consistency was just right.  Instead of deep fried beer batter, I fried chunks of cod that were dredged in my favorite TexMex mix of flour, bread crumbs, cumin, garlic powder, salt, and pepper.  Quite good, and I will probably make it again.  P.S. It's much spicier after a day or so in the fridge.

I mixed the white sauce with some shredded cabbage and let it "wilt" and the flavors marry in fridge about 30 minutes.  Then added that on top of the fish in my taco.  Great flavor!  I omitted the dill (didn't have - don't like), used fresh cilantro in place of oregano, and no fat greek yogurt.  The lime juice really added to it all.  Pan fried my fish with a different floury mix.  I'll keep working on the fish part, but that slaw mixture was tops!

Made this recipe the first time, following the direction exactly, and it was fantastic; my family just went wild.  I used Cobia, since my husband had just returned from a fishing trip in the Gulf, and we had lots of fish.

The white sauce was so popular, I now have a batch on hand in the fridge to use as a dip with chips, on tacos or slightly thinned as a salad dressing.

Thank you for sharing this easy and very tasty recipe!

country:
None
text:
First off the sauce is amazing and I will definitely be making again for fish tacos or other Mexican dishes as outside of the yogurt and jalapeno everything is usually in my kitchen anyway.  The recipe is easy to make and very tasty.  Cilantro if you like it should be included in any Mexican dish I think as it ads a very fresh flavor and I'll be adding it to the sauce next time as some suggest.  I've only made this once and my only complaint really is that the breading turned out too thick and heavy.  It really puffed up so it looked more like fish and chips but I think next time I'll drop the amount of flour a little and probably not whisk it as much, but otherwise it's decent batter and easy to make as well as a lot cheaper then the store bought.

text:
Delicious!  The sauce is what really made these tasty.  It has quite a a kick, but I wouldn't do anything different next time.  I made the sauce about 4 hours before dinner, so the flavors had time to blend.  I didn't have corn tortillas, so we just used flour, and didn't even fry them.  I will try this with corn tortillas next time.  The fish by itself was a little bland, and at first I thought I would spice it up more next time, but considering how flavorful the sauce is, I think I'll just leave everything the way it is.  Thanks for sharing this delicious recipe.

country:
None
text:
Great recipe, better than California's famous Rubio's!  Cheated and used pre-seasoned frozen tilapia from Costco, baked, unbreaded.  I've also used plain frozen tilapia that I seasoned with salt, pepper and cayenne pepper and then baked.  Either one proves to be a huge time saver and healthier alternative!  Sauce REALLY makes these tacos, but make sure to make well ahead so flavors blend.  Based on other reviews, omitted capers, used sour cream instead of yogurt and used half the dill weed.  Hubby is from California and grew up eating fish tacos and says these are THE BEST EVER!  My mouth is watering just thinking about them!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow!   these tacos were amazing.   Just ate some leftovers for breakfast.   Learned that the white sauce is tastier having mellowed.   Next time I will make it ahead if possible.   I used Haddock for myself and my daughter and trout for my husband who is allergic to ocean fish.  Both worked out great.   I found the batter needed a bit more beer as it was too thick and I used a flavorful amber beer.  

Instead of cabbage I used shaved lettuce which I mixed up with lots of chopped cilantro.   Yum!

I did not use a quart of oil but about 1 inch in the bottom of a fry pan.  Cooked for about 4 minutes and then flipped (when golden).  As I almost never fry foods it seemed a shame to throw out that much oil at the end so this way it used less.   

We enjoyed the beer batter enough I will likely use it again too even if not making the tacos. 

I love this website as I keep finding these amazing recipes!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is one meal my whole family will eat, and that doesn't happen very often!  So we have it about once a week now.  I highly recommend serving these with a little bit of pico de gallo and a sliver of fresh avocado on top. What makes this recipe outstanding is it's versatility. You can use any kind of fish; I've made it with cod, haddock and mahi mahi. Or...try it with some shrimp sauteed in a little bit of garlic and olive oil.  Yummy!!  The beer batter can stand by itself, light and fluffy with just enough crunch. Perfect for any kind of fish fry.  I usually make a double batch of the sauce because it is SO good! It's great on baked fish, too!

text:
This were good. I was hoping for spectacular. The sauce was great, but I think I would cut down on the dill, just a little. I made everything exactly as written, the fish was great, crispy and stayed that way, nice suprise. I think the corn tortillas are just too overpowering of a flavor on their own. I will probably not make these again, but may have to use the sauce recipe for other dishes, as I did think it was quite good (Oh, actually I did change one little thing, along with all other ingredients I added about a teaspoon of fresh grated lime zest to the sauce, I try to incorporate some whenever using the juice, I feel it makes it a little more "fresh" tasting).  I tried the corn tortillas simply heated on a hot skillet, and I also tried frying them in oil, both ways did not appeal to me... I think I'm more of a flour tortilla kinda gal, they seem to allow the flavor of the filling to come through a little more.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious. It was the first time I battered and fried something; it was slightly messy but not too difficult. I added a splash more beer to the batter to get a slightly thinner consistency; it was very thick. I don't have a fryer, so I heated an inch of vegetable oil in a heavy duty pot on medium high. I swirled the oil in the pan a bit, so it would cover the fish fillet while the one side was fru=ying about two minutes, and then turned the fish over with a spatula to cook the other side for two minutes. Both sides should be a nice golden light brown. The batter was light and crispy. The sauce is so tasty and I didn't make it ahead.  I omitted the jalapeno and capersand used 1/8 t. cayenne. I thought the sauce was enough for one pound of fish. Will certainly make again.

Very Yummy! The sauce was very tasty. My husband said he thought it was really good and he doesn't care that much for fish! I used tilapia.  I decided to broil it because I wanted to do something easier and less messy. Broiling was a mistake. I could tell that it would be much better fried. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for Christmas dinner, 2010 and it was just outstanding.  Don’t use GROUND oregano-use CRUSHED.  Let the cream sauce age for a few hours to a day to allow the flavors to meld.  Using canned/pickled jalapenos was just fine as opposed to fresh jalapenos.  Finally, don’t rinse the capers.  Some recipes suggest that rinsing capers are a good idea, but the salty/bitter taste of the caper straight from the jar (minced of course) really enhanced the sauce.

None
text:
This is a great recipe, the sauce is great, however I had to remake the beer batter as I learned the colder the better - get that batter cold, almost freeze the beer, then stack it in a bowl on Ice like a double boiler  - my wife also prefered some seasoning in the batter other than what was mentioned, once I had cold batter, I dug it - see the cold reacts differently in the hot oil than a room temp batter, it was much crispier and lighter even - I also jumped the temp on accident to 400* and got a better result...

text:
I have made these several times and they are always a hit. My husband and his friend used to eat these all the time in San Diego while in the Marine Corps and they swear by them! I also add a little salt and cayenne to the beer batter, otherwise it is a tad bland (but you can always add more white sauce!!). I also make the sauce a day ahead of time when I can, it is much better on the second day after the flavors have time to get together.

text:
I only used the batter portion of this recipe and it was very good, and made them with mahi mahi, which in my opinion is the best fish for fish tacos. The only difference I did was to add a little cayenne pepper and a little ancho chile pepper to the batter after mixing. I did find that I needed to add a little more beer in order to get the batter to the consistency I wanted - but wow, the flavor of the fish was FANTASTIC! I served them on small tortillas (not fried)with some homemade tarter sauce, shredded cabbage and a few squeezes of lime. Will definitely make again!!

text:
The sauce for this recipe is AMAZING!! I omitted capers (I don't like them) and subbed some cole slaw for cabbage, otherwise followed the recipe exactly. Well, I used Mahi Mahi, which is what I had on hand, but white fish is white fish! We love spice, and it had a great kick. I can see how this would be a little much for some though, so add the jalapeno and cayenne slowly. The beer batter for the fish was perfect. This will be our beer batter from now on. Perfectly crispy! I added a little Panko and some spices, which I recommend. We also didn't deep fry this - we just tossed a little EVOO in the pan, sliced the fish into fish stick-size pieces, and it was perfect. Yum!! -- We made this two nights in a row. Holy cow , is it good! The second time I added more seasoning to the beer batter as well as a little hot sauce. I added minced garlic to the sauce - why not? We only had 1 piece of Mahi, 1 of salmon, and some shrimp, so I made them all. Still awesome! This is a really versatile recipe, which makes it extra nice!

text:
The sauce alone is the best!!! I've never added the capers though because I do not like them. I also only add 1/2 of the cayenne and it's still enough heat for us. Either way, this is by far one of my favorites meals/recipes ever as well as my husbands. The beer batter is wonderful but whenever I feel like eating lighter I use grilled or broiled tilapia seasoned w/ chili, onion, & garlic powder, lime juice, salt & pepper & it's out of this world. I also buy bagged coleslaw mix to save prepping time. I garnish my tacos with homemade pico de gallo, lime wedge & cilantro...OMG I'm salivating just thinking about it!

text:
What a hit! I don't normally like to deep-fry things, but I recently broke down and bought a liquid thermometer, so I figured I'd give these a shot; besides, my hubby brought home some dorado (mahi mahi) that he caught, and he really wanted fish tacos. The batter was perfect (I use a Pacifico beer) and the white sauce was awesome! I made a double batch (based on other reviews) and I'm looking forward to using it as a veggie dip or even salad dressing. Yummy! I served these with Avocado & Corn Salsa and Refried beans w/out the Refry (both from this site) and this was one successful dinner party. I guess I'll be making fish tacos more often :-) Thanks!

text:
YUM!!  I am from San Diego - born and raised and these tasted just like home to me.  I made a cilantro jalepeno sauce of 1/2 carton of sour cream, 1/2 jalapeno, big handful of cilantro, juice of 1 lime, salt and pepper.  Put into a blender until smooth and then add 3/4 cup of mayo to thicken.  With this sauce it made the fish tacos to die for.

I tried this recipe again and it was FANTASTIC!!I sliced the fish into thinner filets and used flour tortillas and it was sooo good!! I served it with black beans and brown rice and can't wait to have the left overs... I'm so glad that I tried it again!!

text:
The sauce was very good with a unique flavor.  I think I would use all mayo no yogurt next time.  Love mayo, but don't like the tang of yogurt.  Don't have a deep fryer, and hot oil scares me, so it probably wasn't as hot as it should have been.  My fish was a bit mushy although the batter was crisp.  The battered fish could have used a but more seasoning itself.  I might use the sauce again for fish. As for fish tacos, I won't be making them at home again soon - too much trouble for not as good a flavor.  Couldn't see using prepackaged frozen fish like some suggested either.

text:
I was so suprised by the jalapeno.  I didnt have cayenne pepper, so I used a bit of paprika.  I will NEVER do that again!  I dont think I can use the full amount of cayenne pepper, but it does need some.  I ended up using the whole jalepeno pepper though, no seeds.  I dont like capers, so I omitted those.  The sauce was even better the next day.  I froze the leftovers, so I will see how they thaw in the next week or two.  Didnt want to waste that yummy sauce.  The batter on the fish was really yummy and thick.  I would prefer to bake these instead of fry, so I might try that next time.  Super yummy and very colorful!  Thanks!

text:
I suppose I'm mainly rating the beer battering. I changed so much otherwise. I used Henry Weinhard's Private Reserve for the beer, and I used sole for the fish. Instead of deep frying it, I pan fried it in margarine and then broiled for about 7 minutes to finish off the cooking process. As far as the sauce goes-- I ended up doing fat-free sour cream with salsa, oregano and lime juice mixed in. It was kind of plain, but good. My lettuce I was going to use unfortunately went bad before I made this. So all in all, it was plain as a taco the way I made it, but the fish itself was good.

I loved this recipe.  The white sauce is phenominal.  I did not have capers, but it was fantastic anyway.  I suggest making the sauce in advance.  The flavors mix and become bolder and more delicious if it is chilled for 4-5 hours prior to serving.  I used popcorn fish bites from the grocery store rather than battering my own cod on one occasion and it was still great!

text:
These are THE BEST fish tacos I have had since vacationing in Oceanside...  The sauce is REALLY good and the batter was perfect.  It was a little spicy for the kids so I will use only 1/2 tsp cayenne pepper next time. 
The only change I made was used fresh lemon juice instead of lime (didn't have on hand) and omitted the jalapeno pepper..I used a lb of talapia and fried in my cast iron skillet.  To avoid the fish fry smell in my house I had my husband fry on the grill burner outside...I also served with homemade pico de gallo...Sooooo good!!!

Just had this tonight and really enjoyed it. I liked the different flavors that you got with the fried fish, cabbage, warm taco shell, and cold sauce. My husband loved the beer battered fish and after eating two tacos went back for more fish. It is a little time consuming so will not be a staple in our meal planning but I will definitely make it again.

text:
I made this last night & they were great! My husband loved them- said they were by far the best fish tacos he has ever had.  I had fresh wild caught cod.  I followed the recipe completely but left out the capers and dill weed, just because I did not have it on hand.  The batter is thick but it coats nicely.  I filled the pan with oil and heated it up before I added the fish.  They browned nicely.  The dressing came out really good.  I used Hellmans with cannola oil and fage plain yogurt along with the spices and jalapeno.  I will definitely make this again and add the capers and dill weed.

text:
We live on the East Coast and had never tried fish tacos before, and this was the first recipe I found on AllRecipes.  My teenage boys were skeptical to say the least, but we all loved it.  That said; I'm not good at deep frying, and one of my sons can't have gluten, so I had to modify the batter recipe for him.  I finally just gave up and now I just substitute the fried fish with blackened tilapia.  The first time I did it, we all missed the crunch of the fried batter a bit, but now several times later, no one even remembers that's the way they're supposed to be made, and it's much healthier without it!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was AWESOME!!!!!  My husband loved it and so did the baby.  :)  I didn't have the cornstarch so I just omitted it and the batter was fine without it.  The batter went on really thick so I scraped alot of it off, it only takes a tiny bit of batter.  It cooks really quick.  The sauce is AMAZING!!!!!  The sauce combined with the beer battered fish really makes this dish!  Can't say enough about how good the sauce is...INCREDIBLE!  I used a whole jalapeño, about 3.5 inches long, and it wasn't too spicy at all.  The capers went in fine, too, and I went heavy on the cumin because I LOVE cumin.  I used Mexican crema instead of yogurt and it was great.  The consistency wasn't runny, like the recipe said, it was very creamy and delicious.  I also didn't have the dill but didn't miss it, perhaps it would have been even more amazing with it, haha!  I didn't fry the tortillas, just warmed them, and this all came together so quick, it was great.  Oh, also, I didn't deep-fry, I pan fried the fish in whole fillets, then chopped it up to put in the tacos.  Great, great, great.  I added chopped cilantro and sliced avocado to top the tacos off, and it was a hit!

I try really hard to make a recipe as stated but I just couldn't with this one mostly because I didn't have items on hand and this was a much needed quick recipe for dinner. That being said - it was very good!  The key ingredient is the sauce.  I must say that I am not a big fan of fish tacos but my husband is.  So, here's what you can do in a real pinch - use frozen fish.  I was trying to use it up before the date.  This was fish in a box so it certainly wasn't fancy.  We used lettuce because we didn't have cabbage and again, I will state the key is the sauce.  It saved this whole hodge podge dinner.  Can't wait to make this again exactly as stated.  It could only get better.  I will use flour tortillas next time (personal preference).

I've used this recipe for years, and love it mostly for the sauce, but I gotta add my 2 cents here. I PROMISE you will love this...I pan fry talapia with a little Panko. Now...include the following for your toppings: shredded red cabbage, cilantro, avocado, and bleu cheese crumbles.  AWESOME.  Also, for my sauce, I use plain greek yogurt rather than plain yogurt.

text:
I was really not expecting to like this but I figured at worst I could have fried fish and lose the rest so I tried it.

I really loved it the batter turned out perfect and was very easy to make. 

On the sauce I found that it's a little spicier than I would like and next time I will cut the cayenne back by about 1/4. Possibly because it was so spicy there was way more sauce than I needed. Not a problem I froze the rest and used for the next batch. It actually tamed it down a little bit. so if you freeze leftover sauce expect it to be less spicy when you thaw it. Other then that it was just like it was fresh.

I made this gluten free by substituting the 1 cup flour with 3/4 cup brown rice flour and 1/4 cup sorghum flour. And I used Green's GF Amber Ale in place of the beer. I also substituted the mayo for Veganaise, because of other allergies. It was great!!! The second time I made it I forgot to put in the baking powder, but it was still good. Also, I didn't have any jalapeños or capers, so I left that out, the sauce was awesome even without it. Also, I used tilapia because it was on sale, and again... Great!

This recipe is DELICIOUS! To save on calories, trans fat and room for dessert, sprinkle fish fillets with seasoned salt and BAKE. Do not fry. Takes approx. 15 minutes in the oven at 350, depending on size of fillets. Wonderful variation to regular tacos!

text:
Heres the deal. Marinated cubed Tilapia with canola oil,chopped jalepeno,chili powder, lime juice and chopped cilantro for 20 min. Throw on a grill pan at 400 degrees, sprinkle kosher salt on fish pieces as they come out. Used sour cream instead of yogurt( thats all I had)and used the coleslaw mix in the bag(no dressing)-added thinly sliced red onion, fresh salsa and cilantro on flour tortillas(use the small ones!)    Amazing! My boyfriend who hates fish tacos went back 4 times!!

This is a very good and simple recipe.  I added some extra spices (mainly cumin and hot pepper), black beans, sliced avocado, red bell pepper (to the slaw), fresh salsa, cilantro, and lots of lime.  For the fish breading I used brown rice flour (instead of AP), 1/2 c beer, 1 egg, a dash of brown sugar, and flavored it with lots of cumin, hot pepper, and some salt.  FANTASTIC!!  I highly recommend giving this a try!

I sprinkled frozen cod with chili powder, salt and pepper and poured a bit of lime juice over the top (before the seasoning).  Good, not great.  Probably prefer the cod on its own unless frying.

text:
TACOS/FISH:
UPDATE:  Made these a second time and noticed the flour I had used was "better for bread" flour.  Well there was my problem!  So I went and got a proper all purpose flour and these were just perfect perfect perfect! I cooked mine till they are a little darker than needed because I like it extra crispy.  These were a total hit with everyone I made them for!! 

ORIGINAL: Made recipe exactly as described.  At first I tasted a fish taco right after i took it out, w/out any taco fixins.  I was kind of bummed cuz it seemed almost doughy.  However, once put in a taco w/ sauce and cabbage, etc, it was PERFECT. It's not a fish n chips type batter, but its awesome and I'll make it again.

SAUCE:  Made exactly as shown.  I made that first and let it sit in the fridge to let the flavors merge and it was SO good.  Used it the next day for grilled fish tacos as well. I'll prob make this sauce for other stuff too, i loved it!

userID:
7288783
Display Name:
jck
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars

I found this recipe getting close to capturing the dish, but the batter was a little bland and seemed to absorb more oil than I'd like.  Could be I didn't use a thermometer to assure the heat recommended. (?)  I used safflower oil to get nice heat without smoking and kept it at medium heat.  I could have used a recommendation for amount of time for frying, but "until browned" worked ok, fish was not over or under cooked.   Next time I would add a little more salt and add garlic powder to  the batter dry ingredients.  

The sauce was wonderful until I added the cayenne, it tasted uncooked and flat.  If more heat is desired, I would go with more jalapeno.  I've used about 1 tsp cajun spiced butter from the grocery store (by the fish counter where I shop) for this flavor and it works better.   The lime was sublime. Next time:  fresh dill.  I find cumin overpowering, especially uncooked, so I omitted it.  

 This recipe does not include ingredients for Pico (cabbage, onion, cilantro, tomato, jalapeno, lime, salt and pepper).  So, you haven't lived until you have it with pico on top of it.  The contrasting flavors of cilantro, cabbage, lime, crisp fish and corn tortillas is amazing.  Although some in my family prefer flour tortillas, and this is pretty good as well.  

There is definite promise here, I'd like to see a little more healthy options for it and the spices fine tuned.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-09-01T14:32:21.473
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
3359358
Display Name:
Lilacs
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took frozen breaded haddock, and put it into the pizza oven.  We made the yogurt sauce, decreasing the cayenne.  In addition, I made a simple tomato salsa: tomatoes, cilantro, jalapeno, onion, vinegar, lime juice, & sugar.  The combination was heavenly.  I also made a mango salsa.  Both salsas with the yogurt sauce was delicious.  We do not like corn tortillas, so we served it with flour tortillas, and lettuce (no cabbage).  It was quick, easy, and amazing.  Why fuss with the mess!  A pizza oven gives it a nice crisp on both sides, unlike the conventional oven.  I have left over sauce, and salsa.  Can't wait to try it with blackened tuna and grilled salmon.

text:
I would give this recipe a 4.5 - it was good but missing something - could not figure out what.  The beer batter for the fish was good - I did add a little extra salt though. The white sauce was very good - I used fat free yogurt and light mayo. I did not have cayenne pepper so I used chili powder instead. I also added a bit of kosher salt to the white sauce. I made 1/2 cod and 1/2 talapia - everyone liked the talapia better. I lightly fried the corn tortillas - sprinkled a little table salt on them as well. Definatley a recipe to make again - we topped them with pico de gallo. I think next time I may just bake the fish and try it that way to decrease the calories and fat.

This is my new favorite lunch/dinner/snack!!! It's so light and tasty. I seared my fish in a tiny bit of olive oil with no batter. Just added some spices (salt, pepper, chili powder, paprika). text:
Wow, wow, wow!!! I can not say enough good things about this recipe! It turned out GREAT! I'm not a huge fish fan, but my husband is. Therefore, I'm always looking for a fish recipe to make him happy & that I'll enjoy as well. Well this one certainly fits the bill! I changed a few things based on personal preference and what I had on hand. I left out the capers and subbed taco seasoning for the cayenne pepper. I also used coleslaw mix instead of shredded cabbage. I don't own a deep frier, so I just heated the oil in a deep frying pan instead. We both absolutely loved the results, and this one is going into permanent rotation! Thanks for the amazing recipe!

text:
Let me start by saying I just had three leftover fish tacos...for breakfast. These are delicious. I did make a couple of small adjustments to the sauce - adding cilantro and chili powder for color and flavor. Next time I think I'd season the batter a bit more - the texture was perfect, but the flavor could be bumped up a little. I also served it with some homemade pico de gallo and slices of avocado.  All in all, this was fantastic. And since Friday fish fry is a huge thing here in upstate NY, I'm going to use this beer batter recipe to make a killer fish fry soon - and the sauce and red cabbage would make a great slaw on the side.

text:
these were a big hit with my dinner guests, some of which were fish taco veterans and said they were the best they'd ever had. i served them with salsa (from the Moosewood cookbook), avocado and refritos, some plantains sauteed in butter, brown sugar and cinnamon and  "Margaritas to Die For" and it was a great combo. I live in NZ and was cooking for Kiwis, so I halved the jalapeno and cayenne in the sauce but it still had a great kick to it. I had some sauce left over so I combined it with the leftover cabbage slaw and made a spicy southwestern cole slaw. yum.

Display Name:
Love2cook32
isPro:

413

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3854907.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was beyond good!!  My whole family loved it, even my 7 year old.  My family loves spicy so this worked out really good.  The sauce is very spicy so watch out.  I double the sauce (I cooked 1.5 pound cod) and had lots left over. So to re-heat the fried fish the next day, so that it is crispy again, is put fish on a cookie sheet and broil in your oven for a couple of minutes on each side. Watch it so it does not burn. It comes out nice and crisp just like the day you cooked it.  I had a lot of sauce left over so what I did is mixed it with the rest of the slaw mix(used that instead of  cabbage) and let sit for about 4 hours and we ate that with our ribs days later which ended up very tasty...spicy but tasty!  This is a very good recipe and would recomend to anybody!! Hope this review will help others! Thanks!**EDIT**: I HAVE MADE THIS RECIPE MANY TIMES NOW..THE KEY IS WHAT KIND OF INGREDIENTS YOU USE FOR THE SAUCE. THE FIRST FEW TIMES I USED SOUR CREAM AND LIGHT MAYO NOT YOGURT AND MAYO. THIS TIME I USED SMART BALANCE SOUR CREAM W/ MAYO AND IT WAS NOT NEAR AS GOOD.  I THINK YOU SHOULD USE WHATEVER YOUR USED TO EATING.. I THINK NEXT TIME I WILL TRY YOGURT NOT SOUR CREAM. **UPDATE** DID THE YOGART AND MAYO THAT IS THE BEST FOR THIS SAUCE

text:
OK so we tried it with both mayo and miracle whip, and both plain yogurt and sour cream and the best combination is definitely regular mayo and sour cream. (the miracle whip gave it to weird of a tang) No capers, no problem! Doesn't need em.  Used small flour tortillas and panko breaded cod from costco, and purchased the coleslaw mix and pico de gallo from the grocery store.  We devoured them! Made them for the family while we were on vacation and my dad loved the sauce so much he dropped the fish into the bowl of sauce when he went for seconds - It's all about the sauce! This is a must have recipe for Lent, but it may be a sin to eat them they are so dang tasty!

Off the Richter Scale Good!  I eyeballed the tortillas to cut the fish into logs that would fit just right in the taco.  Didn't have yogurt so I used sour cream and a pickled jalapeno.  Halfed the cayenne too because I knew better.  Good Grief -- these are better than the Baja Street Tacos in Mexico!  My boyfriend was moaning with delight as he ate them and kept complimenting that they were the best he'd ever had!  The batter is divine and the sauce is over the top!!!  Thanks so much for the fabulous recipe!!!  UPDATE - I made these another time and was out of cayenne pepper so I added some bottle hot sauce - still great!

This is my first review on this site, I just had to comment on this recipe - it's so easy and goo-oo-ood! I used frozen battered fish fillets (I really don't like the hassle of deep frying) and served with homemade pico de gallo. The white sauce and cabbage tastes so unbelievably good together, it's like they're long lost soul mates or something :D We had a little left over the next day so we eat tortillas with just white sauce, cabbage and pico de gallo for lunch, I almost didn't miss the fish at all, so I guess you could even make these vegetarian tacos!

Made this tonight as fish & chips. Omitted the tacos. It makes a wonderful fish fry. The taco sauce is a little runny for fish & chips, though, so you may want to use tartar sauce. Also, salt the fish after frying. I live on the Northshore of MA and this is just as good if not better than any seaside pub fare.

text:
Pretty good, like others have said, the sauce was the real superstar here. The only change I made was to use sour cream instead of yogurt because that's what I had on hand. I did have some problems with the batter not sticking, but I think that was an error on our part... we don't fry a lot and didn't know what we're doing. Will probably make the sauce again and serve over grilled fish next time!

*UPDATE* I've made these a few more times since then, and I've just been making frozen beer battered fish fillets. We didn't miss the taste or hassle of breading and frying our own fish. Once again, the sauce is a-m-a-z-i-n-g, give it a try!

text:
I was a bit skeptical about this recipe because of a few of the ingredients. I gave it a shot because I know that people in San Diego know whats up when it comes to fish tacos.  I was pretty stoked that I tried this recipe.  The batter was a bit too thick for my liking, but that was probably my fault for not draining it off of the fish for a long enough amount of time.  It had a great flavor all the way around.  I used Heineken for the beer, which I normally don't drink.  I used white corn tortillas instead of regular ones.  I also switched out the Jalapeno for a half of a Habanero pepper.  I also used fresh cod instead of frozen.  Will definitely be making again!

text:
I was looking for a "beer" fish batter and saw this one.  I got distracted making the batter and added in the spices for the sauce by mistake and it came out TERRIFIC!  Will make this "Mistake" again. I dried the fish portions and dusted them first with the dry-blended batter mixture before I added the beer & egg - turned out I had way too much batter anyway for my 1 lb. fish package. Do not use fryer basket - drop battered fish into fryer bowl as fish floats up while cooking and no messy basket to clean to say nothing about all that yummy crispy wasted batter on the bottom of the fish which gets stuck right to & through the basket grids.

text:
I can really only rate the sauce for this recipe.  The only change I made was adding a little salt and cilantro.  I blended it in the food processor to maintain a smooth consistency, which I think is better. The sauce definitely has a kick with both jalapeno and cayenne pepper...but I like spicy food.  I think next time I would cut down the amount of lime juice. I used fat free yogurt and light mayo and it turned out ok.  It is not exactly like the white sauce on the fish tacos in San Diego...but decent enough. It made for a yummy fish taco! For the fish, I used Old Bay Blackened seasoning which gave the fish a tasty kick too.  Top it with cabbage and homemade pico de gallo and you are ready to go.

wonderful recipe! I have been looking for a fish taco recipe as it doesn't seem as popular on the east coast as it is in California. The sauce is perfect; I've used both sour cream and mayo and the recommended mayo and yogurt- I can't decide between the two though- both are yummy. This sauce is a bit too spicey for the kids but perfect for us! This one of the few recipes I've come across that I havn't had to tweek.

text:
I messed this up somehow =(  But still giving it 5 Stars fr THAT SAUCE!  I have ate 2 corn tortillas with JUST it!!  My fish tastes AWFUL.  I have never cooked with Cod before, so am not sure what I did wrong but I marinated it in some lime juice, olive oil, S&P, ginger, garlic.  OMG it is SO nasty!  It is ok, but the finish is so bad it makes you spit it out.  I decided to not fry it and go with the lighter option of pan frying.  I don't know what I did wrong, but UGH!  I didn't use Jalapenos in the sauce or capers, and cut back on the cayenne bc of our little one.  But its a DELICIOUS SAUCE.  I also made crab cakes and might eat the sauce with them too!  Great recipe, don't know what happened to my fish, but I can ONLY imagine how tasty it would be!

text:
Really good!! The only change I would make would be more salt in the batter and possibly the sauce (I am a salt fanatic). 

I also used low fat sour cream and mayo. It was amazing. :) I served it with a side of cucumber and tomato lime salad, and an avocado half. All sprinkled with fresh cilantro. Yum. 

Also, for those of you who do not have a deep fryer or a thermometer, I didn't either. I just let the oil get really hot and gauged how the cooking was going by how fast the fish browned and adjusted temperature as needed.

text:
Loved this.  I don't have a deep fryer, so simply fried it in a pan with a lot of oil.. a little messy that way, but definately worth it.  Sauce was delicious.  I left out the capers, my husband has a strong aversion to them.  I thought it tasted great withouth.  Don't skip the cabbage, it doesn't add a lot of flavor, but it adds in a great crispy crunchy texture that really gives this taco a nice mouth feel.  I want to use the batter to make onion rings next time, I will plan to have some available.  Delicious.

These are awesome!! I ran across this recipe at leased a year ago. They are a favorite in our home now. When I want a quick dinner I just buy fish sticks. This sauce is so great... The best I have ever tried. I always double the recipe. It is hard to find good fish tacos now that I have this recipe. It really is all about the sauce. When I do a double batch I add about a quarter tsp and one jap. GREAT Recipe... You wont regret trying this one... Thanks for sharing, We all love it!

AMAZING!  My family said they wanted to eat this every week.  I didn't fry the corn tortillas, just warmed them up.  Also, I topped off the tacos with some cilantro and used tilapia for the fish because that's what I had.  You can really use most white fish for this recipe and it would still be great.  I don't own a deep fryer, so I just heated about an inch deep of corn oil in a deep skillet until very hot and tossed in the fish (turned them over when they were golden brown). This one is a keeper!

text:
It was very delicious, there were a few things I had to leave out because I didnt have them on hand and I grabbed this receipe at the last minute.  The white sauce was sooo good, i had also baked zesty potato cubes, and ended up topping them with the white sauce. . .mmmm mouth watering now thinking of it.  I didnt have any jalapeno, and i used flour tortias because my children are not wild about corn, I also subsituted shredded lettuce for the cabbage, and frozen fish to help shrink the work, and it was still very good.  I plan on trying this with grilling my fish next time.  I only gave it four because i wish there was a healthier way to make this delicious meal!!!!!  I would say it was a bit spicy for me, but I like everything mild so. . . to each their own!

text:
So yummy!  We are also from southern California, and this recipe perfectly satisfies our craving for fish tacos without having to go out to eat.  As some of the other reviews mentioned, this recipe needs salt!  I add 1 1/2 tsp. to the batter, as well as a light sprinkling to the fish itself before dipping in the batter.  In addition, the sauce needs salt to taste. I also substitute tilapia for cod.  Delicious recipe.

text:
YUM, YUM, YUM!!! I used Gordon's beer battered fish cooked in the oven (fresh fish is hard to come by in Colorado!), served with Fridays onion rings (will try Ora Ida fries next time, same oven temp as Gordon's & my husband perfers fries). Made the sauce, using sour cream instead of yogurt (no capers- ick!) while fish & onion rings were cooking in the oven. I fried the tortillas in a small 8 in fry pan in a tad bit of oil. On the table: a plate for each one of us, plate of tortillas, plate of fish, plate of onion rings, bowl of sauce & bowl of shredded cabbage (I think shredded lettuce would be good to!). We each made our own tacos. The sauce was spicy but not too much, it was just right. It was fun, good hearty food! Thanks Tanya, I will be making this again!

Wonderful!  I usually don't change recipes before reviewing, but, because we're on a lowfat diet, i brushed some of the sauce on fillets and grilled them, and softened the tortillas in a hot, dry frying pan.  Also used lowfat mayo and nonfat yogurt.  I'm sure they are fabulous as prepared in the recipe, but even with the lowfat alternatives, my husband and I both went bonkers over these.  Thanks for a new and exciting way to serve fresh fish.  My husband says he will catch more, and fillet them all, just to have these tacos again!

text:
The sauce is incredible!!  It's a little spicy, but blends well with the other flavors ( I put some in a bowl and added extra yougurt so it wouldn't be too spicy for my kids).  I did bake the breaded fish,like another reviewer mentioned, to cut back on fat.  I wouldn't recommend it, you lose flavor and texture if you don't fry it (that's okay if your not after that little cruch).  I've been looking for a sauce like this for awhile, and now I've found it.  Thanks for sharing.

Ps.  I used the extra sauce over crab cakes the next day.  SUPERB!!

The sauce was very good--but very spicy!  Next time I'll only add 1/2 the cayenne and jalapeno.  I didn't fry the corn tortillas, and steamed them instead.  BIG MISTAKE.  They tore and fell apart while I was trying to eat them, plus the flavor was lacking.  I will try this recipe again, just less spicier and with fried corn tortillas--or steamed flour tortillas.

region:

country:
None
text:
These tacos were fantastic!!  Even my roommate who says she doesn't eat fish is having the leftovers today for lunch!  I added a little garlic salt and cayenne to the batter, subbed sour cream for the yogurt in the sauce(it's what I had on hand) and added a few cilantro leaves along with the cabbage!  The batter was the best I'd ever had and will use to make fish and chips or breaded veggies in the future.  The sauce was very tasty and I'm going to try it as a marninade for grilled chicken.  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I love the white sauce recipe.  Instead of frying it with a breading which is more traditional here in San Diego I just use halibut or talipia and blacken it with spices and fry up with a small amount of olive oil.  Another short cut we just use the angel hair cabbage from the ready produce section.  The only change I made with the white sauce was using a group up chipolte which gives it a real smokey taste.  Great recipe.

text:
I used the sauce with oven fried cod rather than traditional deep frying.  I also used fat free mayo and yogurt to make an extremely low fat meal.  I think the sauce was pretty good, it was just a different taste than I was expecting.  I was hoping for a fresher for baja-tasting sauce and this wasn't it.  I may make this again, but it probably won't become a regular.  One comment: I was a bit skeptical about the addition of the lime juice, but after tasting it without the lime, I decided to add it anyway, and I'm glad that I did!  It really lends alot to the flavor...and it doesn't come out tasting lime-y!

text:
I usually sub baked, breaded catfish fingers & only a generous 1/4t of cayenne, which makes it plenty hot for us. But the flavor of the sauce is great! You MUST use fresh lime juice (had only fresh lemons one time, and it wasn't nearly so tasty). But no matter how you choose to make the fish, with that sauce, some thinly sliced cabbage and pico de gallo if you have it, you CAN'T go wrong. Big tortillas help too, although a neighbor on a diet brought her own sm low-carb tortillas, and she raved about these.

text:
Quite good, but I did make some adjustments to make the recipe healthier and easier.  I thawed frozen mahi mahi fillets while I made the sauce.  Then I chunked the mahi mahi, and cooked it with a bit of olive oil on the stovetop, adding some jerk seasoning and a dash of taco seasoning while cooking.  Total time to make this yummy, healthier fish taco meal:  about 20 minutes.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe, tried it exactly as noted the first time. Frying fish is not yet my forte! Bought frozen battered fish to speed up and simplify (young kids at home).. I used slightly different spices (what I had on hand) Used coriander (not all like it!) instead of oregano as it has more of a citrus flavour. I know fresh is best but since we had jarred pickled jalapeños in the fridge, I used about 6 slices. Chilli powder instead on paprika. I used some of the white sauce and tossed a coleslaw mix with it and refrigerated well in advance of eating. Use leftover sauce to drizzle over fish, which I put on top of the coleslaw!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I modified this recipe and it turned out great, especially since I'm new to cooking and have never cooked cod.  I beer battered the cod but covered it with panko crumbs and prepared it 2 ways: 1) air fried at 350°F for 10 min one side, 5 minutes other side, 2) pan fried in veggie oil on medium high heat for 8 min/side.  I didn't really taste a difference in the texture.  I used red cabbage and mixed the sauce with it, saving half of it to spread on the tortillas.  I don't like corn tortillas so used flour tortillas, browning them on the top of my toaster.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6873875.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I heavily altered this recipie to make a super easy version.  One of these days I need to make a dish true to the recipie.  Firstly, I used frozen fish fillets.  That took half the trouble away!  Breaded or beer batter seemed about the same.  Second, I blended the sauce in with thinly sliced cabbage to make a slaw.  Keep in the refriderator a day before using.  I left out the pepper because I tend to find these recipies too hot.  Added pepper flakes to taste after making slaw.  Thirdly,  find that corn tortillas are often broken or break easily.  I coated one side with olive oil and baked in a toaster oven to desired crispness.  I used two per taco so I could rotate them to hold together any imperfection.

text:
Yummy.  This is a Baja fish taco, I'm assuming.  Guess that's what it is because they are usually fried and sound similar.  We eat them here in Central Cali, too.  We like to use grilled fish though which is not traditional but more healthy.

We also like a sauce that is not white but can't seem to replicate it.  Thought it was chipotle something or other but now think maybe sriracha added to something. There's a tartar sauce flavor as well.  The best in our opinion but can't seem to get restaurants to reveal.  If anyone knows, let ME know.  LOL.

text:
The first time I tried this recipe fish tacos were not a thing in Canada, but I had heard about them from friends who live in California. This recipe is amazing but I was not quite sure how it stacked up. Since then, fish tacos are available everywhere, but I have never found any recipe or restaurant that compares to these. These are so tasty! I make them often and for dinner parties for friends and always get rave reviews. The white sauce makes it and it must be pared with a good pico di Gallo and guacamole. Enjoy!

Eekkk! I looked forward to making these after reading all the reviews. I’m from the South so you do not find fish tacos around here. This was my first time having a fish taco and I was quite disappointed :( ok, so somebody drank my beer for my beer batter so I had to improvise and used milk (another reviewer did also). I was unimpressed by the batter but It was not made accordingly. But was still very bland. Even without making the batter and many even grilled theirs, they still raved about the sauce. I was super excited about the sauce! I followed the recipe with every ingredient and measurement. I was still very unimpressed! The sauce isn’t terrible, just a big let down after reading all the excellent reviews. I had to force these down bc I didn’t want to cook another meal for supper. My husband ate his with a tortilla drenched in ketchup and disliked the sauce. I’d also like to add, I love different and fresh, earthy flavors. I am not a picky eater by any means. The only food I hate is sweet potatoes. These just won’t be happening again ??

I love these! The only seasonings I used in the white sauce were the capers, salt, lime juice and hot sauce.
