country:
None
text:
I made this with sole instead of cod, omitted the oregano as I did not have any, and used gluten free beer and flour, but those were the only alterations that I made. I have made excellent fried GF fish before this, and wasn't going to alter my recipe, but thought I would give this a try. I wish I hadn't. The batter is bland as written, unless you salt and pepper the heck out of it once it's fried. The white sauce is okay, but too many flavors are going on at one time. It's not a bad taste, but I didn't feel any of the ingredients could either shine through or play nicely with the others. It actually tastes alright on its own, but it didn't stand out on the fish.

None
text:
I made several substitutes because I did not have all the ingredients.
Instead of the egg and beer wash I substituted a flaxseed/water mixture combined with a cup of miso soup.  I used panko breadcrumbs seasoned with dill and pepper instead of the flour mixture. 
Replaced deep fryer with pan on stove and used sesame seed oil.
Replaced cabbage with massaged kale.
Substituted yogurt with mustard, actually a mixture of sweet-sabi mustard and deli mustard.
Lastly, used pita bread instead of tortillas.

They were very good.   Loved the sauce and I did make changes.
 I had no yogurt so I used sour cream and eliminated the capers.   It was a wow.   Hesitated about using the entire jalepeno pepper but it worked.  I will be using this sauce on other things too, I liked it that much!   Maybe even a salad dressing.....

I would rate this 4 1/2 starts but I don't know how to make it a half star.....

text:
I absolutely love this recipe!!!  The white sauce is the BEST--and I've tried others.  Hint:  You can sub fish sticks (pick a healthy one with no trans fats) and skip the fish frying step) and you'll have AWESOME tacos.  One of these days, I'll make my own fried fish using the directions in this recipe but, in the meantime, take a chance with the pre-made fish sticks--you won't be disappointed (unless you're in SoCal and think there's a difference, which I wouldn't dispute)  but I haven't had them in their place-of-origin so I'm extrapolating.  In any case, I couldn't be more pleased with this dish!  PERFECT for a hot summer dinner!

This time for the sauce I used 1 cup sour cream instead of yogurt.The yogurt made it too tangy to the point of being overpowering of the other flavors (which I thought would be impossible).Put the lime juice in by small increments and taste as you go because you can't  "un-lime" if you over do it.
I omitted the jalapeño and  substituted the 1/2 tsp cayenne for 1/4 teaspoon of Ancho chili powder and 1/4 tsp of good quality Hungarian paprika.
Still spicy and great flavor,but not "bar food" spicy which is good if you don't like food hot enough to make your nose run.
I also used Mexican oregano crushed finely instead of regular  oregano.The sauce was a pleasing compromise between overly hot(to the point of muting other ingredients) and overly creamy/plain.If you enjoy the dill and caper flavor primarily, simply omit the chili/cayenne/paprika/jalapeño. ..then it is VERY similar to taco del Mars white sauce ;-)
This is my 5th time experimenting with this sauce.

userID:
9147600
Display Name:
jnnpppnk
isPro:

1

54

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/819833.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
It's the sauce! Yogurt + Lime + Miracle Whip
1) Salt Cumin Pepper Cilantro Butter? - melt and toss together.
2) Oregano Jalepeno Cumin 1 TBsPicklejuice vs Dill Cayenne Greenolives vs capers Pepper Cilantro
SALSA: Cilantro RedOnion GarlicPepper(Lowry's) Tomatoes, or MANGO Salsa.
Savoy Cabbage + ColeslawDressing + Miracle Whip (or Lettuce).
Serve with Black Beans or Rice. Cheese is unnecessary.

Muy bueno! * Double the lime & jalapeño. Prep chipotle with some lime juice, add some olive oil and use to marinate the fish. Fry, bake or broil. * If jalapeño is too sour for you, replace with smaller amount of habanero. *Side with beans and brown rice: use 1/3 less water when boiling rice. Add a can of black beans with the rice. Do this before the fish since brown rice takes about 25-30 minutes to soak up the water. Subtract even more water and throw in a can of stewed tomatoes as well. I like to add garlic powder. *Avocado or guac works well as side too. 
*Beer, or ginger ale. * Add cilantro and/or red onion as a garnish or into the cabbage. *Success with salmon is possible.

I love this recipe, it was easy to follow and turned out great! 
I did change some things:

- I only used half of the jalapeño that was called for,  which was lots of heat for me. 
- I used arrowroot flour instead of regular to see how it would work, turned out great! (Stella was the beer I used, just in case you were wondering) 
- I didn't have mayo, so I used Miracle Whip
- I added red cabbage, red onion, cilantro, and pineapple on top = Amazing!!

The white sauce was great.  We pan fried our fish.  From another recipe, I made my own cabbage.  Combine 1/2 head of a small cabbage (cored and thinly sliced, 1/2 medium red onion thinly sliced, and cilantro) in a large bowl and squeeze a lime half over it. Drizzle with the  1 tablespoon vegetable or olive oil, season with salt and pepper, and toss to combine. Taste and add more salt and pepper if necessary; set aside.

text:
Well, let me start out by saying I made a huge mess preparing this....grease , flour and batter everywhere!  The first batch ended up with batter/fish that cooked onto the bottom of the fryer basket. Had to let this cool before scraping the mess off.  So I wised up with the subsequent batches.  Since fryer was small, it took 4 batches to make. At this point, I decided not to fry the taco shells since we were hungry.  They were very good!  The sauce was a pleasantly different combination of flavors, even though I left the jalapeno out and halved the red pepper.  I do think the fish should be salted a bit when done frying.  I may try the grilling suggestion someone made to make a lighter dish, but the recipe is a keeper!

Wow...this was great.  I have been doing a "clean eating" boot camp for a couple of months now (no dairy, soy, corn, gluten etc.)  so had to alter this a bit. text:
I'm giving my review for the fish batter only as I didn't have all the other ingredients and ended up using sour cream with lemon juice and adobo seasoning for the sauce. But the beer batter...omg, it's delicious! I used light beer and the flavor was not overpowering and the texture was crispy but light and the fish was so tender. It is best eaten right away as it can get soggy but if it does and you reheat it, it's still good. I made this twice and used my favorite fried chicken batter mix but it didn't taste as good so I'm gonna stick to the original recipe and mix it from scratch. Will definitely make this recipe again :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I absolutely loved this recipe.  These are the changes we made:  1) Fresh cilantro, red onion, tomato, jalapeno (husband only) & Romaine lettuce added on top of the taco; 2) No cabbage or oregano; 3) No jalapeno added to the white sauce; 4) Rinsed fish & seasoned with Old Bay about 2 hours before cooking; 5) Used sour cream instead of plain yogurt; and finally 6) I do not own a deep fryer, so I just added a couple inches of vegetable oil to a deep pan & used a meat thermometer to check the temperature. This was my first time frying a fish & there were no problems. Great recipe.

text:
I am in love with fish tacos!! I have cooked this with the beer batter (substituted beer with club soda, as I don't drink) and it was good. But I personally love this with a healthier breaded blackened tilapia. I love the sauce but I didn't use the capers because I didn't have them on hand and I used sour cream instead of yogurt. This is better with the crunch of cabbage but it tastes good with shredded romaine lettuce as well. I also like to put a bit of Pico de Gallo on top. Delicious and adaptable recipe. If nothing else, make the sauce just to taste creamy, tangy, and dill flavors. YUM!!

text:
So good!  So so good!!  We absolutely love the sauce.  I make these with shrimp usually but the fish was lovely, too!  The first time I made these I battered the shrimp but as we do not have a deep fryer I did it in a large pan.  Came out a bit fluffy (I over battered....) but was a hot mess (the stove and air in my house).  Also to reduce the calories (if you are into that sort of thing, I am not usually!) I have made the sauce and marinated shrimp in a bit of olive oil, lemon juice, salt, pepper, and garlic and grilled them on skewers.  AWESOME!!!!!!!  Combine with Chef John's tortillas and you will never eat from a food truck again.

text:
My husband and I absolutely loved this recipe!!! I did change a couple things... My husband doesn't like spicy so I added only on jalapeño to the white sauce but I doubled everything else! I seasoned the fish before dipping in the beer batter instead of coating with flour and in the beer batter I added a whole can of beer instead of one cup! I put cole slaw on the taco and white sauce with Pico de gallo and served rice and black beans on the side! My husband wasn't too sure about fish tacos so I was hesitant to make these at first but he was talking about them all night long!!

Great fish tacos. The trick is finding good authentic sauces (not that the one included is not good). In coastal Mexico, the actual tacos from the hundreds of stands are very similar, it's the choice of sauces that separate the good from the great.

userID:
12599767
Display Name:
Eva Casillas
isPro:

25

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4337973.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The whole family loved it. My kids had never tried fish tacos before, so they were hesitant. But there were no left-overs. Update: The second time I did not have any cornstarch, but the batter was fine without it (probably a little less crispy). I used two pounds of fish with the same amount of batter and it was just enough. I didn't dust the fish with flour first, just put all the fish pieces into the batter until ready to fry. And I used cilantro and dill to season the sauce (tastes just as good with sour cream instead of yogurt- but yogurt is preferable) with a dash of garlic powder and a little sugar since the amount of lime juice was too strong ("juice from one lime" is too vague). My 4yo didn't like it in a taco but did like the fish bites dipped in the sauce.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
On the sauce, I followed the recipe except for the dill. I hate dill. Well, I did add 1/8 tsp of ancho chile powder. I so wanted to fry the fish, but my new diet and inner voice said no.... This time I listened. I pan sautéed and seasoned the fish with salt and pepper and chili powder. I free styled a cabbage slaw. I finely shredded some cabbage and a carrot. I made a slaw sauce with some honey, lime juice, oregano, and cumin. It was amazing. This Recipe is great because the sauce and slaw can be made ahead of time and can be doubled or tripled for multiple meals during the work week. If you pan cook the fish or even bake it, dinner can be done in 15 or 20 minutes if the sauces are pre made. I made a guacamole and added it to the tacos. A squeeze of lime makes these perfect. I made these with California rock cod. This fish didn't cook well in the pan, it is a soft flake that kind of fell apart. This could also be user error (points to self). Plus side, the fish was incredibly moist and fresh tasting.

userID:

Display Name:
icebaby028
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Since my husband likes grilled and I like fried fish, I decided to make this both ways. I cut up the fish into approx 2 ounce slices and seasoned with salt and pepper. For the fried, I coated it with the beer batter which was DELICIOUS. For the grilled, I added olive oil and lime juice to the marinade for more flavor. We really couldn't decide which one we liked more because we felt both were great in their own way. I took another reviewer's advice and picked up some cole slaw from Fairway (theirs is not smothered in mayo) to substitute for the raw cabbage.  That worked out GREAT and added wonderful flavors.  However, I didn't love the white sauce. I thought it tasted great when it was just yogurt, mayo, lime juice, and dill weed. But after I added the oregano, cumin, and cayenne pepper, it completely changed the taste and not for the better. Next time I think I will skip those 3 ingredients and try adding Sriracha instead. Also, I chopped up fresh cilantro and diced up onions to sprinkle on top of the tacos.

text:
I didn't care for the heavy batter of the fish for a fish-taco.  This batter would be perfect for fish and chips but for tacos I want something lighter - like panko coating.
But THAT SAUCE!!  Loved it!  I keep thinking about it and other ways to use it.  It is delicious.  I mixed some of it with the cabbage for coleslaw and used more on my taco.  I used fresh oregano and fresh dill since I have them in my garden.
I am making this sauce again tonight for grilled chicken and fried green tomatoes.  The sauce is definitely a keeper!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was AMAZING and super easy. I tossed the cabbage in the sauce (saving some to add on top) and threw some carrots in there for color. A little dollop of pico and some fresh avocado slices to finish the assembled tacos. Nice n simple. The best part was that I could get everything ready in advance and then quickly fry the fish when people arrived. A trick to good, crispy, and NON oily fried fish is to lightly dust your pieces with flour, coat in the batter and then let them sit on a wire rack for about 20 min (this allows the batter to seal around the fish a bit, protecting it from getting saturated with oil when you fry. ANyways, they were BOMB and easy to add a personal touch to.

text:
The white sauce alone gets 5 stars!!  And for those who don't like reviews with modifications, read no further.  I ALWAYS modify.  I marinated and grilled mahi on the gas grill instead of frying cod.  My fish marinade was lime zest plus juice, 2 pods of fresh grated garlic, salt, pepper and half a beer.  We topped tacos with homemade pico (from this site) shredded cabbage, and that heavenly white sauce.  Delish!  I've made the white sauce twice now, the first time I substituted minced green olives since I didn't have capers, and it was great both ways!  Both times, I used sour cream for yogurt, and low fat mayo, because it's what I had on hand.  I also used only 1/4 tsp of cayenne, because 1 whole tsp sounded cruel and unusual.  ;)

Display Name:
Jennifer Korpak Bechtel

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1301605.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the perfect fish taco recipe, and it's an easy one to modify if desired. I make a healthy version of this. My changes include pan sautéing red snapper seasoned with salt, pepper and garlic powder in ghee (drawn butter) until it flakes apart. For the shells we use corn tortillas or large romaine lettuce leaves (low-carb version), and finally a modified sauce. I use 6 oz. low-fat Greek yogurt mixed with 1/4 c. extra virgin olive oil, along with the recommended seasonings plus lime zest and the juice from half a lime. Super yum! Favorite toppings also include the shredded cabbage, tomatillo (green) salsa, chopped onions, and cilantro. It's my go-to fish taco recipe.

Even my most supportive eaters were pushing it around on their plates, thanking me for my effort.  Ouch!  I liked it more than anyone in the family, but I had to admit the batter was bland.  The sauce was kind of good, but still disappointing.  Possibly user error, but I watched the video - twice!

text:
I had never tried making fish tacos with fried fish because I generally make a lighter grilled version, but this recipe is SENSATIONAL!!! I used olive oil for frying and used light mayo, light yogurt and light beer and it was still amazingly delicious.  We also used Mission brand carb balance tortillas and lightly fried those in the olive oil too and between that and the sauce, it made the dish.  Of course it's still fried but it's well worth that splurge you've been saving up for.  We can't wait to use this sauce on other dishes, it's THAT good.  Seriously, make these tacos you will not be disappointed!!

text:
Amazing! I loved it. The family couldn't get enough!   I didn't have regular yogurt, so used the Greek honey yogurt.  That bit of sweetness enhanced the flavors even more.  The batter seems a bit thick so I thinned it a little.  Letting the battered fish drain on a rack while I finished the prep and while the oil was heating insured more even frying and a lighter batter coating. Baking the frozen battered fish fillets is a good idea ODGIRL.  I didn't have cabbage on hand, so stopped by KFC for a container of theirs - a great tasting time saver!

country:
None
text:
I was very disappointed in the beer batter mixture because this recipe has gotten such great reviews. It was very bland, so next time I will salt the fish as it comes out of the oil. The white sauce came out pretty good, I had to tone down the heat for myself since I'm 8 months pregnant and heatburn is my number one enemy. So I cut down on the cayenne pepper and did not add the jalapenos either. Also, I did not put dill weed either since I am not too familiar with it. And next time I will top with cabbage and cilantro. Most authentic tacos have cilantro and cabbage on top anyway.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a regular meal for us now.  The batter makes the perfect fish for tacos (we typically do tilapia).  The sauce is excellent, though it improves with time so try to make it a few hours early if not the day before to allow the flavors to come together.  Do be sure to include the jalapeno and capers for bite.  I use mostly sour cream with a dot of mayo instead of yogurt, since I like the additional tang and it works well with tacos.  Serve with pico de gallo or salsa and fresh cilantro.

text:
Delicious! Like many, I didn't do the breaded to save on a few calories, especially with the mayo sauce and all. (which was great!) I went a little light on cayenne and jalapeno and it still had a zip. I seasoned the fish with cayenne, garlic powder, paprika salt and pepper. Don't be afraid to go generous on seasoning the fish, too... I think I went a bit too light. Definitely something I'll make for a group that's pretty easy, but very pretty! Especially with a little cilantro and lime off to the side and some black beans.. yum!

text:
This review begins with an error, and it gets a 5 based on my mistake. I just blazed ahead and popped all the dry spices in with the flour, and wondered how people could say the batter didn't have much flavour with all these spices.  THEN I noticed  the spices were to go in the sauce, not the batter. Oops!  But what a wonderful mistake.  This batter had amazing flavour.  So I recommend putting the dry spices in with the flour.  Put them in the sauce as well. I don't think you will be disappointed.

Absolutely scrumptious!! I served these with a side of cucumber and red-onion relish marinated in red vinegar and a quick homemade salsa (which was more like a pico). My only suggestion, as has been noted in other reviews, is seasoning the fish more. I added some seasoning but not nearly enough. Overall, though, I would take this recipe hands-down over restaurant fish tacos - and that's saying a lot! Even my husband, who hates fish, ate one and liked it. This recipe will become a staple in my home. Superb!

text:
These are are sooo good that I'm eating them as I type this review. I'm a sophomore in college from Charleston, SC. I LOVE FISH I've been eating it just about everyday since I came back to school in august. I'll tell you guys the truth, fish tacos were one thing I said I'd never eat, but I was young and very ignorant. With the way I have been eating fish I have been wanting to try new recipes and fish tacos were naturally up next. Boy am I glad I did! The sauce was the best part! I was a little weary of the capers since I have never had them nor heard of them. The fish was bland though, but probably due to errors on my part as I'm a novice when it comes to cooking. But it was still great because of the sauce!. I took the adivce of some other reivewers and added pico de gallo which always makes a taco better, about mincing the capers super duper small, about using ginger ale if your out of beer, and using cole slaw mix to save time. I think I'll toss the capers next time I just ate one, gross.  But overall this was an awsome recipe and very quick for people who have no time such as myself.

text:
I loved this recipe.  But I think everything was a little understated. I'm not a person who's into really spicy food so I cut way back on the jalapeno so that left the sauce kind of mild so I added a little more dill and cumin.  I used Orange Roughy and Tilapia because that was all I had.  I seasoned the fish before dipping it in the batter because the first few pieces I made came out kind of bland.  I also used fish that was still a little frozen.  That made it easier to work with.  But this was delicious. My husband chose not to have his tortillas fried. He said it was too much grease.

i mostly chose this recipe for the sauce and i'm so glad i did! the only thing i changed was to leave out the oregano and to use half the amount of mayo. turned out spectacularly! tangy and spicy and full of flavor. as far as the fish goes, i just covered some tilapia fillets with a decent amount of cajun seasoning and grilled them for a few minutes til they were moist and delicious. what an awesome combination! the cajun spices perfectly complimented the tangy sauce. throw on a little freshly made pico de gallo and some avocado slices and you've got an unbelievable delicious AND healthy dinner!

These were delicious. I did use flour tortillas as we prefer them and did not put as much cayenne pepper as it called for but it was really good. I doubled the sauce but won't next time. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/162827.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used tilapia instead of cod and modified this recipe to be gluten free and both my husband and I thought the tacos were delicious.  I used Red Mill GF flour, Green's GF beer, and ALL corn tortillas.  I served with purple cabbage and sliced avocados to add a little more texture.  I don't like too spicey, so I cut all the spicey ingredients in half and the white sauce had just enough spice to satisfy. I also don't have a deep fryer, so I just heated up some oil in a pan and cooked the fish about 2-3 minutes on each side and it turned out great.  Sometimes GF flour doesn't fry or cook as well as regular flour, but it was suitable for this recipe. Yummeez!

This is one of my favorite recipes but preparing the fish is neither quick or easy. Do your self a favour and buy your breaded fish at Costco (Trident brand). It is good fish and they only sell it at Costco where here in Az. Getr a bag of cole slaw at the store and chop cilantro. It is so quick this way, that I found myself up at 3AM fixing them in 15 mins. honestly, these are awesome!

Ok. Here goes...  The white sauce was great...  I went with a suggestion from another review & used sour cream & mayo. The fish was ok IMHO because Talapia is'nt the best fish around yet it is an all around good fish. I don't typiclly like fried fish but wanted my wife to try fish tacos & she is NOT a fish person.  All said she did like the tacos so that's a win...  Next time I'm going to use a mahi mahi steak seasoned, grilled and cut into strips.  I may try chipolte paste instead of the jalepeno.  All in all this is a great way to introduce a non- fish eater to fish tacos...  Thanks for the white sauce recipe...

text:
Delicious! I've made this many times, and each time I use crispy fish sticks. I've used corn tortillas, and soft wheat tortillas, which I prefer for adding a healthy touch. Once in a while, I'll toss a bit of garlic salt into the white sauce and use fat free mayo with the yogurt. No matter how you make this up, you're going to love it. After assembling the taco, sometimes I'll put a little salsa and/or a small squirt of ranch if the white sauce comes out too spicy (I use the whole jalapeno, seeds and all). Remember, lots of cabbage. A wonderful recipe, I highly recommend it.

text:
I've been making these for about two years now and I think the best way to make them is to make the white sauce the day before so that the flavors blend well. Also, after lightly flouring the fish, adding a little bit of Cajun seasoning and after frying them, adding a little bit of salt, this gives them more flavor. Make sure to use good quality beer as well, I've tried it with the cheap stuff and the batter is not as light and crisp. Everything else is exceptional....soooo good on a hot summer day!

Display Name:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
UPDATE: INITIALLY MY (NOW) HUBS AND I THOUGHT THESE WERE JUST "OK," BUT WITH A FEW CHANGES, THIS HAS BECOME ONE OF OUR FAVORITE MEALS (AND QUITE POSSIBLY BETTER THAN OUR LOCAL MEXICAN HANGOUT'S TACOS). I FIND THAT CORONA IS THE PERFECT BEER FOR THIS BATTER (THE BONUS??? I HAVE ENOUGH LEFT TO MAKE BEER MARGARITAS!). I HAVE ALSO FOUND THAT A MILDLY WARM (200 DEGREE) OVEN IS PERFECT FOR KEEPING MY FISH WARM BETWEEN BATCHES. MY FISH ALWAYS REMAINS AS CRISPY AS IT WAS STRAIGHT OUT OF THE FRYER. A COUPLE OF FINAL TIPS - A) SALT EACH PIECE OF FISH IMMEDIATELY UPON REMOVING FROM THE FRYER (ADDS FLAVOR) AND B) ADD A SQUEEZE OF LIME TO EACH TACO (YUM!). THESE SIMPLE STEPS HAVE HUGE IMPACT!!! My bf and I have been craving fish tacos ever since making SCARY76's fish tacos a few months ago (which were mediocre at best). I'm not sure whether these taste anything like Rubio's (the chain is not local to Chicago), but they were decent nonetheless. I guess I'm just a sucker for the real deal - you just can't beat fresh fish tacos from the little vendor stands in San Diego, IMHO.  Other than having a little trouble with the batter sticking to our fry basket (it was quite messy), these turned out as expected. Assembled as recommended with the addition of a dollop of fresh pico de gallo, made for a nice presentation. Tortilla chips and Bacardi mojitos completed our meal. All in all, these were good, but not "blow your socks off good" as the ratings suggest. Thanks anyways, roweena :)

text:
Great recipe!  The sauce is amazing. I modified it a bit using some of the suggestions here - I used fresh cilantro instead of oregano, 1 tsp fresh dill, used 3/4 cup nonfat yogurt and 1/4 cup light miracle whip (next time I might try all yogurt!), used 1/2 tsp canned jalepenos and 1/4 tsp cayenne pepper (we found this to be the right amount of heat - the full amount would have been mind blowing!).  Like some others, I used tilapia fish and grilled it with just some salt, pepper and lime juice squeezed over it (healthier choice than frying) Absolutely delicious - will definitely be making again!

text:
I give the beer batter 5+ stars. I've never made fish that way before and it came out great! I used Dover sole, which I don't think was a good idea because the fish was a little mushy. Great flavor and super crunchy though! The sauce...that I only give 2.5 stars. It was just ok, not even "good". I followed the recipe to a "T" so it wasn't something I did. I can see potential in it however. What I don't see is why so many people raved over it. Overall, this recipe was good, but needs some tweeking

text:
These were great!  As others have said, the sauce was fabulous...I added a bit more salt and a twist or two of fresh ground pepper and it was perfect!  I also used sour cream instead of yogurt.  Will use the leftovers on some chicken tacos today and plan to freeze the rest - I've had pretty good luck freezing sauces like this before.  I also made some sauteed onions and peppers with a bit of kosher salt, fresh pepper, and lime juice, since my boyfriend doesn't like creamy sauces and it was a nice touch.  To the batter I also added a pinch of cayenne and thought it turned out nice and crispy, not too heavy like some beer batters can be.  Definitely a favorite, and going into the regular rotation!  ***Edit - instead of freezing the extra sauce,we actually used it as a chip dip - worked out great!  (I also used sour cream instead of yogurt)

text:
We were very skeptical. I've had fish tacos in some popular restaurants and didn't care for them. I thought I'd try these out and they were excellent!!! Even my picky teenagers ate them. We actually fought about the leftovers! I made them with store bought breaded cod so they are probably even better if you bread the fish yourself. I did leave out the capers and the sauce was a tad bit spicy . I would recommed adding the cayenne a little at a time to your taste.

text:
Another 5 star from allrecipes! We made these with grouper instead of cod. Recipe is worth it just for the beer batter and the wonderful white sauce! I used greek yogurt, which tastes just like sour cream. I always feel healthy when I eat that. I also use greek yogurt as a potato chip dip, but I digress....  We accompanied it with homemade sangria and latin music, hubby says it should be more than 5 stars.

text:
I'm originally from southern CA. where fish taco's are very popular. So I have had my share of good ones. I have since moved away to Northern CA. where the fish taco isn't as popular. Anyways, I had a hankering for some and decided to make my own. Saw this recipe and gave it a try. REALLY yummy! I have used tilipia, cod and halibut, and all versions are good. I have fried them and when I want a bit healthier, I grill the fish. Either way they are very tasty. Tho the fried version is more authentic. I serve with this sauce, Amy's Cilantro sauce from this site, cabbage and lime wedges and it's a little bit of heaven in a corn tortilla!
